Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Processing and Properties of Cellulose Films for MEMS Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this grant is to investigate the feasibility of cellulose nanocrystals as an alternative to silicon for microelectromechanical systems (MEMS). The structure, mechanical properties, surface chemistry, and ability to self-assemble into well defined architectures over multiple scales make cellulose nanocrystals particularly attractive building blocks for advanced materials. In this research, cellulose nanocrystals with controlled size distributions and surface chemistries will be processed to form dry films and fabricated into devices using conventional MEMS fabrication techniques such as lithography and etching. Finally, the properties of the resulting devices will be characterized to yield an interrelation between the cellulose nanocrystal MEMS device properties, the cellulose nanocrystal dispersion microstructure, and film processing conditions.

If successful, this research will enable renewable cellulose materials to be used as an inexpensive alternative to the high-cost electronic grade silicon, which is currently the industry standard for advanced sensor platforms. Results of this research have the potential to transform the MEMS industry, as well as other silicon based technologies. This would have considerable economic impact; Yole Developpement projects the MEMS industry will exceed $13 billion in 2012. Even if the full potential of this research is not realized, it will provide fundamental insight into the processing of nanocylinders for advanced materials applications. The research will also enhance a strong collaboration between Chemical Engineering faculty at Auburn University and Clemson University. The research will contribute to the education and training of two Ph. D. students, one post doctoral researcher, and four undergraduate researchers. Graduate student rotations in each of the PIs laboratory will provide a diverse perspective and training for the advanced materials workforce. The research team will also engage in outreach activities to foster the development of the next generation of scientists and engineers.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) are a key part of the transportation, health care, consumer products, and defense industries. Recent successes in the field of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and microfluidic devices (i.e., labs-on-a-chip) have prompted the need for low cost, disposable, point of care/use devices. Existing micro-fabrication platforms are almost entirely based on silicon. As a result, MEMS fabrication typically involves processes that are energy intensive, require high temperatures, are expensive, and can have significant potential environmental impacts. This research grant enabled developing the scientific and engineering understanding to develop a much less energy intensive and much more environmentally friendly route for making MEMS. We have shown that MEMS can be produced from the cellulose nanocrystals contained within biomass such as trees and waste materials from the forest products industry. The process for making CNC MEMS not only starts with a renewable biodegradable material, it entails much lower processing temperatures and chemicals and greener chemicals and processes. This award significantly increased understanding of the colloid and liquid crystalline thermodynamics affecting processing aqueous cellulose nanocrystal processing and the properties of the resulting films and devices. It also enabled the first free-standing, actuatable, CNC-based MEMS and showed that CNC MEMS enable more readily tailorable properties than can be achieved with silicon. This result promises to have significant impact for the MEMS industry particularly in terms of disposable devices for applications such as point of care diagnostics. In addition to the specific science and engineering contributions, this award facilitated numerous outreach activities and the education of undergraduate and graduate student researchers. 

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2015
Modified by: Virginia A Davis
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) are a key part of the transportation, health care, consumer products, and defense industries. Recent successes in the field of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and microfluidic devices (i.e., labs-on-a-chip) have prompted the need for low cost, disposable, point of care/use devices. Existing micro-fabrication platforms are almost entirely based on silicon. As a result, MEMS fabrication typically involves processes that are energy intensive, require high temperatures, are expensive, and can have significant potential environmental impacts. This research grant enabled developing the scientific and engineering understanding to develop a much less energy intensive and much more environmentally friendly route for making MEMS. We have shown that MEMS can be produced from the cellulose nanocrystals contained within biomass such as trees and waste materials from the forest products industry. The process for making CNC MEMS not only starts with a renewable biodegradable material, it entails much lower processing temperatures and chemicals and greener chemicals and processes. This award significantly increased understanding of the colloid and liquid crystalline thermodynamics affecting processing aqueous cellulose nanocrystal processing and the properties of the resulting films and devices. It also enabled the first free-standing, actuatable, CNC-based MEMS and showed that CNC MEMS enable more readily tailorable properties than can be achieved with silicon. This result promises to have significant impact for the MEMS industry particularly in terms of disposable devices for applications such as point of care diagnostics. In addition to the specific science and engineering contributions, this award facilitated numerous outreach activities and the education of undergraduate and graduate student researchers.
